title: How to Remove Odor from Leather Shoes

steps.title: Combine white vinegar, water, and tea tree oil in a spray bottle.
steps.content: Combine white vinegar, water, and tea tree oil in a spray bottle. Add 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 mL) of white vinegar, 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 mL) of water and 5 drops of tea tree oil into a clean spray bottle. Shake the bottle well to mix it well. [1] X Research source If you don’t have tea tree oil, you can just use the white vinegar and water as a spray. Don’t use apple cider vinegar, which can stain or discolor of the leather.

steps.title: Spray the mixture onto a clean cloth.
steps.content: Spray the mixture onto a clean cloth. Dampen a paper towel or a rag with your cleaning solution, but don't use so much that you saturate it. Then, wring out the cloth before you use it so you only apply a thin layer of the solution. [2] X Research source If it's possible, avoid using a cloth that's been dyed. Some of the color may transfer to your leather shoes, discoloring them.

steps.title: Wipe the inside of the leather shoes with the cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the inside of the leather shoes with the cloth. Work the cloth along all of the interiors of the shoes. Be sure to clean the insole, as well as all the way to the front of the toe box, along the sides, and back to the heel of the shoe. [3] X Research source It may help to remove the laces and lift up the tongue of the shoe to wipe the inside.

steps.title: Dry the shoes with a clean cloth.
steps.content: Dry the shoes with a clean cloth. Right after you wipe the cloth with the cleaning solution, use a new, dry cloth to wipe inside of the shoes. Make sure the insides of the leather shoes aren’t damp, as this could damage them or could even allow new bad smells to develop. [4] X Research source Make sure the new cloth you use is clean and dry. You can use a dry paper towel to wipe the inside of the shoes.

steps.title: Sprinkle 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of baking soda into each leather shoe.
steps.content: Sprinkle 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of baking soda into each leather shoe. After you’ve wiped up the excess cleaning solution, add the baking soda to the inside of each of the leather shoes and shake them well. Make sure the powder penetrates down to the toe and coats all of the insides of the leather shoes. [5] X Research source If the baking soda doesn’t cover the insides of the shoes, add another 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) and shake them again. Baking soda absorbs unpleasant odors. [6] X Expert Source Marc Sigal Shoe Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 January 2020.

steps.title: Allow the leather shoes to sit overnight.
steps.content: Allow the leather shoes to sit overnight. With the cleaning solution and the baking soda inside of the leather shoes, leave them undisturbed for 8 hours or overnight. In the morning, smell them again to see if the odor has been removed. [7] X Research source Set a timer for 8 hours if you don’t plan to leave them overnight. The vinegar will have completely evaporated and dried, so you don’t need to wipe the leather shoes before you wear them. Use a vacuum to remove any leftover baking soda before you wear your shoes. [8] X Expert Source Marc Sigal Shoe Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 January 2020.

steps.title: Steep black tea bags in hot water for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Steep black tea bags in hot water for 5 minutes. Bring a pot of hot water to a boil and then remove it from the heat. Place your black tea bags into the water and allow them to soak for 5 minutes. [9] X Research source Use 1 teabag for each leather shoe. Set a timer for 5 minutes. The black tea needs to be steeped in order to activate the tannins that work as natural disinfectants.

steps.title: Remove the tea bags from the water and let them cool.
steps.content: Remove the tea bags from the water and let them cool. Take the bags of tea out of the water and place them on a plate. Let them cool for a few minutes so you can pick them up with your fingers. [10] X Research source Many black tea bags have strings on them that allow you to remove them without burning yourself in the hot water. Use a fork or a pair of tongs to remove the tea bags from the water if they don’t have strings on them.

steps.title: Place 1 tea bag inside of each leather shoe.
steps.content: Place 1 tea bag inside of each leather shoe. When the tea bags are cool enough that you can pick them up, place 1 of them into the leather shoe at about the halfway point so the moisture can reach all of the insides of the shoe. Don’t squeeze out the juice from the tea bag. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Let the leather shoes sit for 2 hours.
steps.content: Let the leather shoes sit for 2 hours. With the tea bag inside of the leather shoes, leave them undisturbed for 2 hours to allow the tannins to disinfect them and remove the odor. Avoid moving or touching the shoes until they’ve been disinfected to ensure even coverage. Set a timer for 2 hours so you don’t have to worry about checking on them.

steps.title: Take out the tea bags and wipe the leather shoes dry.
steps.content: Take out the tea bags and wipe the leather shoes dry. After the tea bags have been allowed to sit and disinfect the leather shoes, take them out and throw them away. Then, take a dry cloth or paper towel and wipe down the insides of the shoes to remove any excess moisture from the tea bags. If the odor persists, try repeating the process again to further disinfect the leather shoes and remove the smell.

steps.title: Check the packaging to make sure the spray is safe for leather shoes.
steps.content: Check the packaging to make sure the spray is safe for leather shoes. Look for a commercial shoe cleaner or a disinfecting spray that says it’s safe to use on leather shoes. Some disinfecting sprays are designed for cloth sneakers and can stain or damage leather shoes. [12] X Research source You can find spray disinfectant designed to clean leather shoes at drug stores, department stores, and online. If the product is safe to use on leather boots, then it’s safe to use on leather shoes.

steps.title: Spray the inside of the leather shoes.
steps.content: Spray the inside of the leather shoes. Use the spray on each shoe 1 at a time. Hold the shoe upside down and aim the nozzle down into the toe of the shoe so the spray covers everywhere inside of the shoe. [13] X Research source Spray for about 3-4 seconds to fully coat the leather shoes.

steps.title: Let the shoes dry for 5 minutes then smell them.
steps.content: Let the shoes dry for 5 minutes then smell them. The spray disinfectant will dry in a few minutes after you apply it. When they’re dry, give the leather shoes a good sniff. If the odor is still there, apply the spray once more, allowing them to dry a second time. You can repeat the process as many times as necessary, but be sure to allow the leather shoes to fully dry between applications. That way, the leather won't soak up the moisture, which could cause it to warp.
